title: 1615-G
statement: G. Maximum Adjacent Pairstime limit per test3 secondsmemory limit per test512 megabytesinputstandard inputoutputstandard outputYou are given an array $$$a$$$ consisting of $$$n$$$ non-negative integers.You have to replace each $$$0$$$ in $$$a$$$ with an integer from $$$1$$$ to $$$n$$$ (different elements equal to $$$0$$$ can be replaced by different integers).Thevalueof the array you obtain is the number of integers $$$k$$$ from $$$1$$$ to $$$n$$$ such that the following condition holds: there exist a pair of adjacent elements equal to $$$k$$$ (i. e. there exists some $$$i \\in [1, n - 1]$$$ such that $$$a_i = a_{i + 1} = k$$$). If there are multiple such pairs for some integer $$$k$$$, this integer is counted in thevalueonly once.Your task is to obtain the array with the maximum possiblevalue.InputThe first line contains one integer $$$n$$$ ($$$2 \\le n \\le 3 \\cdot 10^5$$$) — the number of elements in the array.The second line contains $$$n$$$ integers $$$a_1, a_2, \\dots, a_n$$$ ($$$0 \\le a_i \\le \\min(n, 600)$$$) — the elements of the array.OutputPrint $$$n$$$ integers not less than $$$1$$$ and not greater than $$$n$$$ — the array with the maximum possiblevalueyou can obtain.If there are multiple answers, print any of them.ExamplesInput4 1 1 0 2Output1 1 2 2Input5 0 0 0 0 0Output3 1 1 3 3Input5 1 2 3 4 5Output1 2 3 4 5Input6 1 0 0 0 0 1Output1 2 3 3 1 1Input3 3 0 2Output3 2 2Input5 1 0 2 0 1Output1 2 2 1 1Input7 1 0 2 3 1 0 2Output1 2 2 3 1 1 2

processed.result:
You are given an array of $n$ non-negative integers. You can replace each 0 in the array with a number from 1 to $n$ (different 0s can be replaced with different numbers).

The goal is to find a way to replace the 0s so that the resulting array has the maximum possible value. The value of the array is defined as the number of integers $k$ from 1 to $n$ such that there are at least two adjacent elements in the array that equal $k$.

For example, if the array is [1, 1, 0, 2], the value of the array is 2 because there are two pairs of adjacent elements that are equal to 1 and 2.

Input:

* The first line contains an integer $n$ ($2 \le n \le 3 \cdot 10^5$) representing the number of elements in the array.
* The second line contains $n$ integers $a_1, a_2, ..., a_n$ ($0 \le a_i \le \min(n, 600)$) representing the elements of the array.

Output:

* Print $n$ integers not less than 1 and not greater than $n$ representing the array with the maximum possible value. If there are multiple solutions, print any one of them.

You are given a list of numbers. Some numbers are zero. You can replace each zero with a number from 1 to the length of the list.  The goal is to choose replacements so that the final list has the maximum number of pairs of adjacent numbers that are the same.
